issues.title: What to do about MTU and Fragmentation
issues.author: asedeno
issues.body:
Standard 802.3 Ethernet frames can be up to 1518 octets in length, 1522 octets when tagged (802.1Q VLANs), and 1526 octets when double-tagged (802.1ad Stacked VLANs).

This includes up to 1500 octets of payload, and the L2 framing itself:

```
- 6 octets       - Destination MAC
- 6 octets       - Source MAC
- (4 octets)     - VLAN Tag (802.1Q)
- (4 octets)     - VLAN Stacking (802.1ad, or QinQ)
- 2 octets       - Ethertype or Length
- 46-1500 octets - Payload
- 4 octets       - Frame Check Sequence (CRC)
```

The CRC can be dropped and recomputed. The rest of the framing must be transmitted in one form or another. Assuming a maximal payload plus the required 14 octets of header, and no VLAN tags, we may need to carry a maximal payload of 1514 octets.

When using this draft over HTTP/1.1 or HTTP/2, the underlying transport is TCP, which provides a reliable and ordered stream of octets. Ethernet Frames are transmitted using HTTP Datagrams and the Capsule Protcol defined in RFC9297, and will naturally be fragmented as needed.

When using this draft over HTTP/3, things get interesting. Ideally, Ethernet frames would be transmitted over HTTP Datagrams using QUIC Datagrams (RFC9221). Such Datagrams are required to fit inside a QUIC Packet, and are therefore limited by the underlying network MTU and further limited by the overhead of H3/QUIC/UDP/IP.

Trivially, if an Ethernet frame is too large to be transmitted this way, we could fall back to Capsules over the connection's HTTP stream. However, this comes with the cost of Head of Line blocking for all frames so transmitted in addition to the overhead of fragmentation.

I think we should recommend some form of MTU negotiation such that Ethernet frames being proxied are guaranteed to fit within the MTUs of both attached networks and the maximum size H3 Datagram for the connection between them.

An added complication is that the path may not be fixed, and so the path MTU may vary over time, and we'll need to think about how to handle that too.

If an operator is in full control of the network and both Ethernet proxying endpoints, they should adjust the underlying MTU to support whatever proxied MTU they require.

When the underlying network MTU is not adjustable and the operator requires a larger MTU than would be supported by the underlying network, fragmentation is necessitated.

- What knobs do we need to provide here?
- What should we recommend with regards to how to tune those knobs?
- What warnings labels should we attach to them?

Let's discuss.

comments.author: DavidSchinazi
comments.body: The MTU implications of connect-ethernet are very similar to those of connect-ip, the only difference is that the amount of overhead is slightly larger. I'd suggest reusing the solutions from RFC 9484. My assumption is that Ethernet doesn't require an MTU of 1500 to work properly, is that incorrect?

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body: You're right, it doesn't. However, this was a concern brought up at IETF 118, and so I want discussion around it.

comments.author: achernya
comments.body:
@DavidSchinazi 
> My assumption is that Ethernet doesn't require an MTU of 1500 to work properly, is that incorrect?

IIRC the Ethernet MTU of every device in a broadcast domain has to match, otherwise you will get blackholing. I believe we can't rely on PMTU within the broadcast domain, because the Ethernet MAC will drop packet-too-big and we don't get the opportunity on the host networking stack to send ICMP packet-too-big messages.

As a result, I think if we want to support full-sized ethernet MTU we need to support fragmentation (unreliable delivery) or do reliable streams.

comments.author: DavidSchinazi
comments.body: Can you elaborate on why the MTU has to match? PMTUD still works fine on the Internet even in the absence of ICMP packet-too-big.

comments.author: achernya
comments.body: AIUI an ethernet frame that is too large for the device's MTU is dropped at the MAC layer, before it even hits any OS or user code. This means that while protocols that do PMTUD can discover and work around this black hole, it won't work for any protocols that expect the local broadcast domain to be "well-behaved". I do suspect that a surprisingly large number of protocols for which we'd want a L2-VPN-style connection fall into this category.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Don't we have experience with connecting jumbogram Ethernets to non-jumbogram Ethernets? Shouldn't we emulate that behavior (whatever it is)?

issues.title: MAC Address filtering
issues.author: asedeno
issues.body:
At IETF 118, some kind of MAC address filtering was suggested. Perhaps a client will only ever present traffic from a single MAC address, so that should be registered as part of the connection and packets from a different source address should be dropped, possibly terminating the connection.

This could be useful for clients proxying a single user/node, but less so for clients bridging whole networks.

Do we want to support this? If so, how should it be configured?

comments.author: achernya
comments.body: Perhaps I'm misremembering, but I thought we had some affirmative nods that this could be a future extension?

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body: If folks want this, I'm not opposed to accepting a PR around it. Otherwise, future extension it is.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: Thanks for closing this issue. I just want to note that this was discussed at IETF-119 and there was agreement to leave this to future extensions. Also I note that we do discuss the risk of arbitrary forwarding in the security considerations. I guess we could add another note that proxies could be configured to limit forwarding to only pre-configured addresses but that any dynamic signalling or negotiation of MAC address filtering is left to future extensions...?

issues.title: E-VPN - leverage or discourage?
issues.author: asedeno
issues.body:
At IETF-118 it was suggested we should take a solid stance on whether or not this should be used as a transport for E-VPN.
Traditionally, E-VPN goes over VXLAN or NVGRE, which are not authenticated. This could provide a strongly encrypted and authenticated transport for data center interconnect.

I don't have an opinion here yet beyond thinking that E-VPN looks big and outside of my own scope of experience. I would want to understand more about where and how it is used.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethernet_VPN
[RFC 7209 - Requirements for Ethernet VPN (EVPN)](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7209)

From the l2vpn final charter[^1]:

> Ethernet VPN (E-VPN) - An enhanced Layer-2 service that emulates an Ethernet (V)LAN across a PSN. E-VPN supports load-sharing across multiple connections from a Layer-2 site to an L2VPN service. E-VPN is primarily targeted to support large-scale L2VPNs with resiliency requirements not satisfied by other L2VPN solutions.

[^1]: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/charter-ietf-l2vpn/

comments.author: achernya
comments.body:
I believe E-VPN can also use Geneve (RFC 8926 Geneve: Generic Network Virtualization Encapsulation, https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8926.html)

I also agree that I think E-VPN is probably out-of-scope initially? But nothing stops a future draft from developing E-VPN over connect-ethernet.

comments.author: dabernie
comments.body: Personally, I would have a tendency NOT to try and match EVPN architecture. Use case for connect-ethernet would be more around "how to leverage Application/QUIC based approach on doing tunnelling" instead of current model.

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body: I don't think we need to say anything about E-VPN in this draft.

issues.title: Why limit to Ethernet? connect-pseudowire?
issues.author: asedeno
issues.body:
Should this draft be made more generic, and draw more inspiration from the PWE3 WG [^1]?

At IETF-118, it was suggested we limit scope, build our minimum viable product, and define our extension points.

The `connect-ethernet` method is definitely limiting scope, and invites a plethora of `connect-${my_favorite_L2_protocol_here}` followup documents.

A `connect-pseudowire` method and associated frame-type negotiation, with an included Ethernet example, could be later extended to support other Layer 2 Protocols. If we go down this path, we should consider the work of the PWE3 WG.

Independent of this, I'll be opening some other issues that reference the work of the PWE3 WG.

[^1]: https://datatracker.ietf.org/wg/pwe3/about/

comments.author: DavidSchinazi
comments.body: My preference would be to keep this scoped to connect-ethernet. Creating connect-something-else when that's needed is a better choice since that'll ensure proper analysis of that specific L2 is performed.

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body: Having thought about this some more, I've remembered that we're not implementing a new HTTP method, per se, but using extended connect for H2/H3 and upgrade for H1. We don't need to invent an L2-specific extended-extended-connect. New values for the `Upgrade` / `:protocol` headers are already cheap.

issues.title: Why are we transmitting the Frame Check Sequence?
issues.author: asedeno
issues.body:
Section 6 of the draft states that Context ID 0 indicates that the Datagram carries

> a full Layer 2 Ethernet Frame (from the MAC destination field until the last byte of the Frame check sequence field).

The Frame check sequence is a four octet CRC that we could recalculate on the receiving Ethernet proxying endpoint. If we drop and recompute it, we eke out 4 additional octets of payload.

comments.author: achernya
comments.body: In CONNECT-IP we left header compression to future context IDs. I think you could do the same here? You're trading off space vs compute power.

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body: Sure, let's return to this in future header compression work if that happens.

issues.title: Frame delivery order?
issues.author: asedeno
issues.body:
Encapsulation Methods for Transport of Ethernet over MPLS Networks [RFC4448] Section 4.4.3, "Frame Ordering," is interesting.

https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4448.html#section-4.4.3

> In general, applications running over Ethernet do not require strict frame ordering.  However, the IEEE definition of 802.3 [802.3] requires that frames from the same conversation in the context of link aggregation (clause 43) are delivered in sequence.

PWE3 provides knobs[^1] to optionally enable frame sequencing and timing if required. Perhaps our this draft should similarly provide for optional frame ordering, and if made more generic than Ethernet, also consider providing more of the features in PWE3.

[^1]: https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3985.html#section-5.2

comments.author: achernya
comments.body: I am not sure we need to do anything here -- link aggregation concerns have knock-on effects for e.g., TCP flows. I think that suggests we at most SHOULD try to maintain frame ordering, but we don't have any mechanisms that will intentionally reorder.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: Sorry for replying late to a closed issue and I agree we should not do anything explicitly. However, we could note that if ordering needs to be ensured, stream mode can be used.

issues.title: Special consideration for Ethernet PAUSE frames
issues.author: asedeno
issues.body:
More from PWE3: 

https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4448.html#section-4.4.5
> In a standard Ethernet network, the flow control mechanism is optional and typically configured between the two nodes on a point-to-point link (e.g., between the CE and the PE).  IEEE 802.3x PAUSE frames MUST NOT be carried across the PW.  See [Appendix A](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4448.html#appendix-A) for notes on CE-PE flow control.

https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4448.html#appendix-A.2 has the specific notes on PAUSE frame.

This does not seem common anymore. We probably still don't want to proxy it. Otherwise emitting or reacting to PAUSE frames do not appear to be in scope for this draft.

comments.author: achernya
comments.body: I think we should not respect PAUSE frames. That can be left to a future extension if we can define a semantic that makes sense. (PAUSE frames can result in DoS if used incorrectly)

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
In the draft we say:

> This document defines a tunnelling mechanism that is conceptually
> an Ethernet link. Implementations might need to handle some of the
> responsibilities of an Ethernet switch or bridge if they do not delegate
> them to another implementation such as a kernel. Those responsibilities
> are beyond the scope of this document

I think his includes also any handling of PAUSE frames. In other words proxy may decide to forward or not forward a PAUSE frame but it's independent of connect-ethernet functionality to decided that.

The only thing we could do is to explicitly name the PAUSE as an example for frames that could be considered. However, currently the document as no dependency on the content of the ethernet frames that being proxies and I think it would be important to keep it that way. That's actually also something we could explicitly mention.

issues.title: Special considerations for VLANs
issues.author: asedeno
issues.body:
Another PWE3-related topic.

https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4448.html#section-4 describes several modes for encapsulating Ethernet over MPLS. Among those are
- Ethernet Tagged Mode
- Ethernet Raw Mode

https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4448.html#section-4.4.1 compares Raw Mode and Tagged mode.

The distinguishing feature is the handling of VLAN tags, specifically service-delimiting tags set by the service provider.

In raw mode, service-delimiting tags are stripped prior to encapsulation, and other VLAN tags are ignored and transmitted as is.
In tagged mode, service-delimiting tags are not stripped, may need to be added if absent, and are processed by the endpoints.

Presently, this draft does not consider VLAN tags, and operates in something closer to raw mode, delegating any details related to VLAN tags up to the user. Do we need to provide any special consideration for VLAN tagging here, or is this delegation sufficient?

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body: I'm going to add text to the effect of: we'll blindly carry VLAN tags as part of Ethernet frames, but recommend avoiding carrying VLAN-tagged frames and using separate connect-ethernet connections for each VLAN.

issues.title: VLAN Tagging
issues.author: gloinul
issues.body:
My reaction to the text added in regards to VLAN tagging: 
"While the protocol as described can proxy Ethernet frames with 802.1Q VLAN tags, it is RECOMMENDED that individual VLANs be proxied in separate connections, and VLAN tags be stripped and applied by the Ethernet proxying endpoints as needed."

Does VLAN tagging need to be signalled on HTTP level? If one is to strip and re-insert or map them rathern than transfer them over the Ethernet tunnel then one might need labels on the request for what VLAN tag to apply if any. In one mental model each connect requrest for ethernet creates an additional ethernet port, which local switching/bridging behavior then needs to be applied to, like tagging. Will thus this virtual ports needs labels to handle this, or even explicit tagging instruction on the other side? How are one otherwise expected to keep them seperated from each other?

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body:
If the VLAN tags are being transmitted in the proxied Ethernet frames, then it should be handled by Ethernet switch or bridge or whatever is handling the bits that are out of scope for the protocol.

If you're using separate connections for different VLANs and stripping/reapplying the VLAN tags, I imagine the VLAN getting signaled in the URL that is used to establish the connection, though not in the form of, "please tag these packets with VLAN tag NN," but more like, "please establish a connection to the WiFi[^1] Ethernet segment." In this case, the Ethernet proxy would be configured to tag those Frames, or would drop those packets untagged onto a port on that VLAN.

The details of how Ethernet frames get to the desired Ethernet segment is outside the scope of the protocol for moving Ethernet frames over HTTP. The details for this should be agreed upon by the Ethernet proxying endpoints in advance.

[^1]: WiFi chosen as an arbitrary example of a thing I've seen separate VLANs for.

comments.author: gloinul
comments.body: Okey, so this might relate then to the client configuration (#16)  aspect and how to build URIs. Is this something one can encode into a URI template for example in a reasonable way?

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body: I think this was well covered in the changes made when closing #19. Feel free to re-open if more discussion is needed

issues.title: Client Configuration
issues.author: gloinul
issues.body:
I would expect that one may still uses URI template to declare how the URI looks like even if there are currently no parameters that require configuration just to make it aligned with the other extended connects. And if one introduce future parameters, like VLAN tags to be applied, then having declared that URI templates is the way to define these URIs would help a lot. 

Secondly, the use of the well known  (.wellknown/masque/ethernet) will require a bit of explanation and a reference to the relevant specs for well known, as well as the URI suffix in connect-ip.

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body:
I dropped the template language when rewriting from CONNECT-IP[^1] because there was a lack of parameters, but the point is well taken.

Regarding references, RFC 5785[^2] is not referenced in RFC 9484[^1]. I'm not opposed to adding one here though.

[11.2. Updates to the MASQUE URI Suffixes Registry](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-masque-connect-ethernet-04.html#name-updates-to-the-masque-uri-s) already exists in this document. We can update it to directly reference section 12.2 in RFC9484[^1].

[^1]: [Proxying IP in HTTP](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9484.html)
[^2]: [Defining Well-Known Uniform Resource Identifiers (URIs)](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5785.html)

comments.author: gloinul
comments.body: I think a reference to RFC 8615 (replacing RFC 5785) would actually be good. Looking back at RFC 9484 I think its text could have been better and clearer.

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body: Sure; I didn't catch the `Obsoleted by` link on the side there and just did a quick search. Thanks for pointing out the updated version.

issues.title: Context IDs being written as descriptive rather than hypotheticals
issues.author: gloinul
issues.body:
Section 5: 
Some of these extensions can augment Ethernet payloads with additional data or compress Ethernet frame header fields, while others can exchange data that is completely separate from Ethernet payloads.

The above is written as it is a fact rathern than a potential extensions that might be defined. Please reformulat as a hypothetical case.

issues.title: Layer separation when determining what is congestion controlled
issues.author: gloinul
issues.body:
Section 9: 
When the protocol running inside the tunnel uses congestion control (e.g., [TCP] or [QUIC]), the proxied traffic will incur at least two nested congestion controllers. When tunneled packets are sent using QUIC DATAGRAM frames, the outer HTTP connection MAY disable congestion control for those packets that contain only QUIC DATAGRAM frames encapsulating Ethernet frames. Implementers will benefit from reading the guidance in Section 3.1.11 of [UDP-USAGE].

Is there need to discuss the potential need to traverse up the stack from Ethernet frames to determine if traffic flow is congestion controlled or identify flows that are? Or is this an overreaching layer violation to accomplish this. I think we have a bit of a problem here and it depends on how the network is being used. A network that predominately transport IP over Ethernet may be possible to assume that it carries congestion controlled traffic. However if there are usages that not IP and run more directly on Ethernet this may not be true.

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body:
There are some interesting opportinities for implementers to inspect the Ethernet frames being transported and make some decisions based on what they see. At the MASQUE meeting at IETF 119, I mentioned the possibility the Ethernet proxying endpoints using TCP MSS clamping to squeeze TCP packets into the (unfortunately potentially variable) connection MTU, for example.

I'm not opposed to an appendix of such ideas for implementers to consider if their use cases warrant it, though I don't want to require such behavior from implementers.

comments.author: gloinul
comments.body: Yes, I don't want to forbid anything but also I don't think we can require anything. I think the text can be clearer on that most mechanism we have to affect these would require analyzing several layers on top of Ethernet and that it is up to implementation to select the trade-off here. So I think appendix or seperate section that is clear on the none requirements.

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body: Calling this resolved with #21. We can reopen or start a new issue if there is more to do.

issues.title: What version of Ethernet is required to be supported
issues.author: gloinul
issues.body: I noticed that there are no normative reference to a specific Ethernet version or versions that is to be supported. I think as an example here is support for 802.1Q required or not by the Ethernet processing at the end of the tunnel?

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body: I think that's largely dependent on what you want to establish a connection between. I don't have any patch cables that list 802.1Q support, for instance.

comments.author: gloinul
comments.body:
So I think the main core of this question is to answer what normative reference should be included in this section 6 sentence: 

"When the Context ID is set to zero, the Payload field
   contains a full Layer 2 Ethernet Frame (from the MAC destination
   field until the last byte of the Frame check sequence field)."

To define what a layer 2 Ethernet Frame is.

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body: I don't know how or if I would want to tighten this up, but I am open to suggestions. This description of an Ethernet frame _is_ very loose, but would we want to tighten it up so much that when 802.1πθ comes out it would not be supported even if those Ethernet frames would trivially handled if the endpoints supported it?

comments.author: gloinul
comments.body: Here we might need more Ethernet expertise. Because I have assumed that most Ethernet extensions are compatible within the frame format. However I do think we need to have a normative reference to what encoding 0 really is.

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body:
As I understand it, IEEE 802.3 specifies the Ethernet frame, and the 802.1Q tag is optional. 802.1ad (Q-in-Q) allows multiple tags. Beyond those two, I'm not aware of additional alternatives. The tags are detectable because when they are parsed as an EtherType, they present as a tag.

The protocol itself doesn't need to parse the Frame, though implementations might want to inspect them and be clever about something (x-ref: #18).

We should perhaps mention 802.3 / Ethernet II, including optional 802.1Q/802.1ad, though reiterate the recommendation that frames carried by the protocol not be tagged, but have VLANs separated into different conections (x-ref: #15).

Do we need to explicitly mention the other [Ethernet frame types](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethernet_frame#Types) here and exclude them? They're not particularly common.

comments.author: gloinul
comments.body:
I think we need to consider if the Connect-Ethernet request at least defaults to Ethernet II, and that if one want to use other formats one would add some request parameter to indicate any other format(s) one want to run. 

Referencing 802.3 appears a good normative reference. Saying this without looking into if there are multiple versions of the spec and we need to point to a particular version. Although I would expect fairly good backwards compatibility.

issues.title: MTU signaling and probing
issues.author: c-taylor
issues.body:
The document should probably make a stronger reference to PLPMTUD probing and discovery to discover MTU.

This connect-ethernet there is also ability and benefit to express the probed value to the client.
Client implementation can then either update psuedo-interface mtu or routing information with tested the MTU, useful for both performance and TCP.

It's also conceivable that MTU can change over time on an l2vpn of this type; This should probably be mentioned, also perhaps also a strategy to detect and update any signaling.

issues.title: Be more specific regarding TLS version and add a reference.
issues.author: asedeno
issues.body:
Generating an issue for @gorryfair from [email](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/masque/G9USoURXa7AcBZJUvrxRtjpAY3I/) on the masque WG [mailing list](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/browse/masque/).

https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-masque-connect-ethernet-07.html#section-4-4
>Ethernet proxying over HTTP MUST be operated over TLS or QUIC encryption, or another equivalent encryption protocol, to provide confidentiality, integrity, and authentication.

Please add reference. I expect TLS 1.3? (or do you explicitly allow TLS 1.2 depending?) Please explain.

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body:
This text was taken nearly verbatim from RFC 9484.

https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9484#section-4-5
> IP proxying over HTTP MUST be operated over TLS or QUIC encryption, or another equivalent encryption protocol, to provide confidentiality, integrity, and authentication.

It's just mandating a secure underlying transport. I don't think we need a change here, but if we can add a reference to TLS if there's demand for it.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: I think it's actually better to not have a reference to a specific version. And I would think TLS is well-know enough that it doesn't need a reference.

issues.title: Transporting things that are not Ethernet frames?
issues.author: asedeno
issues.body:
Generating an issue for @gorryfair from [email](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/masque/G9USoURXa7AcBZJUvrxRtjpAY3I/) on the masque WG [mailing list](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/browse/masque/).

https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-masque-connect-ethernet-07.html#section-5-1
> The mechanism for proxying Ethernet in HTTP defined in this document allows future extensions to exchange HTTP Datagrams that carry different semantics from Ethernet frames.

The I-D title leads a reader to think this is about Ethernet frames, but actually it could be other forms of PDU. Section 5 starts with the 
above text, however the abstract and the introduction do not yet say this.  Please amend the abstract and also add an explanatory text to the introduction.

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body:
I believe this text is being misinterpreted. This is not meant to extend to other Layer 2 protocols beyond Ethernet, but rather to facilitate extensions to improve the efficiency of carrying Ethernet frames.

This text is borrowed from other MASQUE WG RFCs.
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9484#name-context-identifiers
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9298#name-context-identifiers

Some datagrams that are not carrying a raw Ethernet frame could instead be carrying a Capsule for some not-yet-written extension, or some form of compressed Ethernet frame payload that needs to be combined with negotiated state to regenerate the raw Ethernet frame before delivering it to the attached Ethernet segment.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
Yes, this sentence means that you cannot automatically assume that a HTTPP datagram contains Ethernet frame as you could negotiate different semantics for a context ID. However, as @asedeno said there is no intention to extend the scope of this document beyond ethernet. So this is a misunderstanding. Maybe a simple tweak would help:

> ... Datagrams that carry different semantics than a context ID and an Ethernet frame as defined in this document.

Would that help?

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: Maybe - but somehow the document has to clearly indicate the scope of this document is only to forward Ethernet frames.

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body:
Do the abstract and introduction not already state this clearly?

> This document describes how to proxy Ethernet frames in HTTP.

> This document describes a protocol for exchanging Ethernet frames with an HTTP server.

issues.title: Context ID registration undefined?
issues.author: asedeno
issues.body:
Generating an issue for @gorryfair from [email](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/masque/G9USoURXa7AcBZJUvrxRtjpAY3I/) on the masque WG [mailing list](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/browse/masque/).

At the end of section ~~6~~ 5 there is some text that seems to imply this is not yet an interoperable specification. I find this worrying and confusing.

https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-masque-connect-ethernet-07.html#section-5-3
> Registration is the action by which an endpoint informs its peer of the semantics and format of a given Context ID. This document does not define how registration occurs. Future extensions MAY use HTTP header fields or capsules to register Context IDs. Depending on the method being used, it is possible for datagrams to be received with Context IDs that have not yet been registered. For instance, this can be due to reordering of the packet containing the datagram and the packet containing the registration message during transmission.

Why is the working group not finishing at least one baseline method (or does it?) and how to negotiate so that interoperability is possible. Does this mean the spec ought not to be a PS?

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body:
This text is borrowed from other MASQUE WG RFCs.
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9484#name-context-identifiers
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9298#name-context-identifiers

The only Context ID that endpoints must support for this draft is `0`, which indicates that the payload is an Ethernet frame.
https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-masque-connect-ethernet-07.html#name-http-datagram-payload-forma

Negotiation of other Context IDs is left to future work, and their registration is specified to occur using HTTP header fields or capsules. The specifics of those headers or capsules is also the subject of that future work.

As an example of this from elsewhere in the WG, for [CONNECT-UDP](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9298), the [Proxying Bound UDP in HTTP](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-masque-connect-udp-listen/) draft adds a header, Connect-UDP-Bind[^1] to negotiate the feature, and new capsules[^3][^4] to register and unregister contexts[^2].

[^1]: https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-masque-connect-udp-listen-07.html#name-the-connect-udp-bind-header
[^2]: https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-masque-connect-udp-listen-07.html#name-context-identifiers

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: This is simply the extensibility mechanism used for all MASQUE CONNECT methods but there is no further extension needed to support the basic forwarding as as specified in the document. This is the same for all MASQUE CONNECT methods (where we already work on extensions).

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body:
As this protocol:
1. does not require the registration of additional Context IDs
2. leaves open the path by which future work can define such a registration

Also given that other documents in the MASQUE working group already serve as examples for how such a registration might be specified, I don't think any changes are necessary here.

issues.title: What to do with an unknown Context ID is underspecified.
issues.author: asedeno
issues.body:
Generating an issue for @gorryfair from [email](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/masque/G9USoURXa7AcBZJUvrxRtjpAY3I/) on the masque WG [mailing list](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/browse/masque/).

I think this is underspecified.
https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-masque-connect-ethernet-07.html#section-6-4.2.1
> If an HTTP/3 datagram which carries an unknown Context ID is received, the receiver SHALL either drop that datagram silently or buffer it temporarily (on the order of a round trip) while awaiting the registration of the corresponding Context ID.
 
- How does the receiver know the RTT (please explain).
- Can we finish saying what happens… I was presuming that all packets that were buffered SHOULD be finally delivered in order, or MUST be  discarded after the timeout.
- Ought a failure resulting in a timeout discard result also in an error code or at least logging event?

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body:
This text is borrowed from other MASQUE WG RFCs.
https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9298.html#section-5-3.2.1
https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9484.html#section-6-4.2.1

I don't think this requires any changes.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
I agree that I don't think we need to be more specific here or should even try to; it's okay to leave this to the implementation. If you don't have an idea about the RTT or any good value for how long to wait, just drop it.

Datagrams are not delivered reliably or in order. So there is no requirement to order or ensure that all packets get delivered. Re-ordering is explicitly what should NOT be done here and therefore the text does not say that.

Of course you could log if you drop a packet because of an unknown Context ID, however, again this is left to the implementation as I think we generally don't specify this level of logging. Note that the text is explicitly there to say this is not a protocol error because as I said datagram are not reliable anyway and could get drop anywhere at anytime no matter what.

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body:
OK, but this was not immediately clear. So, after reading more, I understand how this could work! I  suspect that I tripped over the last para on context IDs, and in particular this sentence:

 “Depending on the
   method being used, it is possible for datagrams to be received with
   Context IDs that have not yet been registered.”

and I think the draft could be more helpful in that last para. 

 I agree that it would  be helpful reference a "similar" mechanism for Connect-UDP: https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9298.html#section-5-3.2.1; that would have saved me this issue.

And in particular, I’d value adding this to the draft - based on the above:

Note that buffering datagrams (either because the request was not yet received or because the Context ID is not yet known) consumes resources. Receivers that buffer datagrams SHOULD apply buffering limits to reduce the risk of resource exhaustion occurring. For example, receivers can limit the total number of buffered datagrams or the cumulative size of buffered datagrams on a per-stream, per-context, or per-connection basis.

— although personally, I’d also ADD that excessive buffering can also increase jitter and latency to the transported flow.

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body:
Sure, we can borrow that text from RFC9298. It was added to that document during later reviews, and never made it into RFC9848, so also didn't make it here, but it would be a good addition. We may also want to borrow and adjust the surrounding paragraphs.

This text might also apply to the discussion in #36 .

issues.title: Please further clarify how to handle odd Ethernet frames
issues.author: asedeno
issues.body:
Generating an issue for @gorryfair from [email](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/masque/G9USoURXa7AcBZJUvrxRtjpAY3I/) on the masque WG [mailing list](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/browse/masque/).

https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-masque-connect-ethernet-07.html#section-6-5
> Ethernet frames are encoded using HTTP Datagrams with the Context ID set to zero. When the Context ID is set to zero, the Payload field contains a full Layer 2 Ethernet Frame (from the MAC destination field until the last byte of the Frame check sequence field), as defined by IEEE 802.3, with support for optional IEEE 802.1Q tagging (see [Section 9.2](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-masque-connect-ethernet-07.html#vlan-recommendations)).

- Do you strip padding of small frames?
- Do you forward runt frames (too short)?

I assume the answer to both is “no”? - please add text.

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body:
Do we strip padding? No; if there is padding, it is between the MAC destination field and the Frame check sequence field, so it is defined as included in the quoted text.

Do we forward runt frames? Yes, but also no. If we were creating frames, we might have to worry about this. As it is, runt frames should neither successfully enter or exit the proxying endpoints, but can be carried between them.

I don't believe either of these needs additional text, though I am open to adding text to explicitly drop runt frames if others think that is a useful clarification. We would also need to decide if such frames should be dropped on ingress, egress, or both, and it does add overhead of checking each frame's size even though that was probably already done by some other Ethernet-specific bit of hardware or driver with which we are exchanging frames.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
I think we should not be dropping runt frames, the egress or ingress tunnel might phase/check the frames but the connect logic should just forward whatever it gets without modifying it (it might drop something because of buffer overflow reasons but that's not different than any other random drop anywhere else on a link). I also think we should not add specific text because we also decided to not add any specific text for another other ethernet specific checks/things.

Note that effectively the connect method does not even check if it gets an ethernet frame at all; in other words this is not a protocol function to enforce that. However, the protocol is designed for forwarding ethernet frames and therefore might not work as intended if it would be used with anything else.

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: I asked this so that it has been asked. The point is that while other things might be allowed or not, sending runt frames is illegal, except in specific circumstances. The correct answer might be that the egress will only forward frames that the Ethernet specifications allow.

issues.title: Clarifications on handling Ethernet frames
issues.author: asedeno
issues.body:
Generating an issue for @gorryfair from [email](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/masque/G9USoURXa7AcBZJUvrxRtjpAY3I/) on the masque WG [mailing list](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/browse/masque/).

A layer 2 PDU will be received at ingress proxy, encapsulated over the tunnel, transported, decapsulated at the egress, and transmitted out on an interface at the egress.

https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-masque-connect-ethernet-07.html#name-ethernet-frame-handling
> This document defines a tunnelling mechanism that is conceptually an Ethernet link. Implementations might need to handle some of the responsibilities of an Ethernet switch or bridge if they do not delegate them to another implementation such as a kernel. Those responsibilities are beyond the scope of this document, and include, but are not limited to, the handling of broadcast packets and multicast groups, or the local termination of PAUSE frames.

I suggest to add something like the following (adapted form the PWE work that Lars mentioned):

NEW:
> An Ethernet proxy emulates a single Ethernet link between exactly two endpoints. This provides an Ethernet MAC service that will deliver each Ethernet frame that is received at the ingress, unaltered, to the egress at the other end of the tunnel.

NEW:
> The tunnel forwards unicast/multicast/broadcast frames.

I don’t see how this can work with Ethernet frames with IETF protocols unless you forward them, you may of course wish to perform some sort of filtering as well, but that’s covered by the next point.

NEW:
> The tunnel endpoint may provide functions that include stripping, overwriting or adding VLAN tags, physical port multiplexing and demultiplexing, bridging, L2 encapsulation, shaping, filtering, policing, etc.  These functions are specific to the Ethernet technology, and may not be required for this service. These are outside of the scope of ~~PWE3~~ this document and are not defined here.

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body:
> An Ethernet proxy emulates a single Ethernet link between exactly two endpoints. This provides an Ethernet MAC service that will deliver each Ethernet frame that is received at the ingress, unaltered, to the egress at the other end of the tunnel.

I like the second sentence here.

We can explicitly specify that we carry multicast and broadcast frames, though nothing here says we don't. We just don't speak to what if anything needs to be done to handle those frames. Either it's delegated to a TAP interface or similar, or you know how to handle that yourself because you're implementing Ethernet on the other side of the Ethernet proxying endpoint. Either way, the details are out of scope for this protocol.

The third point appears to be expanding on the list of things that are out of scope. I feel they are already implicitly covered, though we can explicitly expand the list if there is interest.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
+1 on adding the first sentence!

I'm okay to add more things we support or don't support explicitly as we already mention somethings explicitly (broadcast packets and multicast groups, or the local termination of PAUSE frames) which are the things that we discussed in some issue in past and explicitly decided to not add any specific handling. However, just naming a few things but not other might be confusing. I guess the other option would be to also remove those things currently explicitly listed and make the text more general instead.

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: See also PR #38 to avoid suggesting that this adds bridging functions

issues.title: VLAN redux
issues.author: asedeno
issues.body:
Generating an issue for @gorryfair from [email](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/masque/G9USoURXa7AcBZJUvrxRtjpAY3I/) on the masque WG [mailing list](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/browse/masque/).

https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-masque-connect-ethernet-07.html#name-ieee-8021q-vlan-tagging
> While the protocol as described can proxy Ethernet frames with IEEE 802.1Q VLAN tags, it is RECOMMENDED that individual VLANs be proxied in separate connections, and VLAN tags be stripped and applied by the Ethernet proxying endpoints as needed.

Sect 9.2: On VLANs, some tighter text could be:

NEW:
> When an Ethernet PDU contains VLAN tags, these are passed transparently through the tunnel.  When an ingress and/or egress interprets the tags that can be present there must be agreement (signaled or manually configured) on how to process each tag at the ingress and the egress. This is not defined in this document.

Question: Can the ingress/egress respect the PRI? (This could be useful to permit). e.g.:

> The ingress MAY consider the user priority (PRI) field [802.1Q] of the outer VLAN tag header when queuing  the encapsulating PDU.  In a similar way, the egress MAY consider the QoS field of the PDY when queuing the frame for transmission.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
The new proposed text by Gorry does not keep the one important bit of information here which is that the client application (that uses connect-ethernet and might parse and interpret the ethernet frames and vlan tags) should use separate tunnel connections per VLAN tag. What we don't say here and maybe want to add is that this would enable differential treatment in the network using e.g. DSCP.

The confusing part of the current sentence is maybe the "stripped and applied by the Ethernet proxying endpoints" part. These are the proxying ingress or egress that use connect-ethernet and might parse and interpret ethernet frames but not the actually ethernet-connect layer endpoint. I think we have not defined the terminology well here and could be more careful in phrasing this (inline with Gorry's proposed text). Similarly it would the those functions that would consider the PRI _before_ passing the frame to the ethernet-connect layer.

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: The new text was NOT intended to replace the way frames were transported, only how the ingress and egress were described. One tag per tunnel seems good to me.

issues.title: regarding MUST when speaking of buffer depth
issues.author: asedeno
issues.body:
Generating an issue for @gorryfair from [email](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/masque/G9USoURXa7AcBZJUvrxRtjpAY3I/) on the masque WG [mailing list](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/browse/masque/).

https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-masque-connect-ethernet-07.html#section-9-2
> Some implementations might find it benefitial to maintain a small buffer of frames to be sent through the tunnel to smooth out short term variations and bursts in tunnel capacity. Any such buffer MUST be limited, and when exceeded any Ethernet frames that would otherwise be buffered MUST be dropped.

- How is this an interoperable test - because there is no size specified?
- I think this could be a place where a SHOULD is better and explain why this is an excellent idea. If the packet is dropped, is the MUST a silent drop; or is this a normal router drop that triggers ICMP when appropriate.

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body:
Previous context: https://github.com/ietf-wg-masque/draft-ietf-masque-connect-ethernet/pull/21

It is more of a possible implementation detail than a part of the protocol itself. I don't see this as something tested during interop. Perhaps a SHOULD is better here. I'm curious what other think. Explaining that limiting how much memory is allocated to such buffering is a good idea seems straightforward, though I don't want to specify what those limits should be.

In email, I said that dropping frames is silent. I suppose in the context where a proxying endpoint has a place to send an ICMP message to, it could generate and send one back out onto the attached Ethernet segment if appropriate, but that feels like it's out of scope for the document.

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: I agree the tunnel endpoints would, if implemented, generate the ICMP messages, and that would be normal for an endpoint to an IP device. This seems a little out of scope.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: Maybe we don't need any normative language here at all. At least the first must is not a protocol requirement but a matter of fact and therefore should not be a MUST. Also that if a buffer overflows, the only option is to drop a packet; so that isn't a protocol function either. The only thing, as Gorry said, that a protocol could define is what to do after the drop, either nothing (silently drop) or some alert/ICMP but I would agree that we don't want to specify this here. Therefore I would recommend to remove the normative language entirely and maybe add a sentence that any actions taken on drop are out of scope for this spec.

issues.title: C-VLAN, S-VLAN and Q-in-Q
issues.author: gorryfair
issues.body: Section 9.2 talks about dot1Q VLAN tagging, but it should also be clear about C-VLAN vs S-VLAN tagging. There could also be a need to mention Provider Backbone Bridges (PBB) where the service is identified by an I-SID (Backbone Service Instance Identifier).

comments.author: asedeno
comments.body:
I would prefer not going into that level of detail here. What I was trying to get at in `9.2 IEEE 802.1Q VLAN tagging` is that while the protocol can carry VLAN-tagged frames, you might get better performance characteristics by carring those VLANs in separate streams without the tags. This also ekes out a couple bytes of payload space.

The suggestion applies to 802.1ad (QinQ) just as well as it does to Q, and leaves to the implementation / deployment how to handle, strip, and/or apply any layer of tagging.

I did not know about Provider Backbone Bridges (802.1ah) before today. To a first approximation it looks like encapsulating Ethernet in Ethernet, and I would rather not talk about it at all.

A strict reading of https://ietf-wg-masque.github.io/draft-ietf-masque-connect-ethernet/draft-ietf-masque-connect-ethernet.html#section-6-5

> Ethernet frames are encoded using HTTP Datagrams with the Context ID set to zero. When the Context ID is set to zero, the Payload field contains a full Layer 2 Ethernet Frame (from the MAC destination field until the last byte of the Frame check sequence field), **as defined by IEEE 802.3, with support for optional IEEE 802.1Q tagging** (see [Section 9.2](https://ietf-wg-masque.github.io/draft-ietf-masque-connect-ethernet/draft-ietf-masque-connect-ethernet.html#vlan-recommendations)).

(emphasis added) suggests that 802.1ah is out of scope, and given that QinQ is an extension of 802.1Q, it too is out of scope.

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: You correctly identified the problem: "you might get better performance characteristics by carring those VLANs in separate streams without the tags." -- Mapping VLANs to connections might be helpful in some specific contexts. I think clarification is needed, stripping VLAN Tags can also have consequences if the other endpoint then forrwards Ethernet frames.
